Journal.Title: International journal of environmental research and public health
Journal.ISOAbbreviation: Int J Environ Res Public Health

Article.ArticleTitle: Temporal Characteristics of Ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) in the Representative City of the Yangtze River Delta: Explanatory Factors and Sensitivity Analysis.

AbstractText: Ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) has attracted considerable attention due to its harmful effects on the ecosystem and human health. The Yangtze River Delta (YRD), China in particular has experienced severe O<sub>3</sub> pollution in recent years. Here, we conducted a long-term observation of O<sub>3</sub> in YRD to reveal its characteristics. The O<sub>3</sub> concentration in autumn was the highest at 72.76 ppb due to photochemical contribution and local convection patterns, with its lowest value of 2.40 ppb in winter. O<sub>3</sub> exhibited strong diurnal variations, showing the highest values in the early afternoon (15:00-16:00) and the minimum in 07:00-08:00, specifically, peroxyacetyl nitrate (PAN) showed similar variations to O<sub>3</sub> but PAN peak usually occurred 1 h earlier than that of O<sub>3</sub> due to PAN photolysis. A generalized additive model indicated that the key factors to O<sub>3</sub> formation were NO<sub>2</sub>, PAN, and temperature. It was found that a certain temperature rise promoted O<sub>3</sub> formation, whereas temperatures above 27 °C inhibited O<sub>3</sub> formation. An observation-based model showed O<sub>3</sub> formation was VOCs-limited in spring and winter, was NO<sub>x</sub>-limited in summer, and even controlled by both VOCs and NO<sub>x</sub> in autumn. Thus, prevention and control strategies for O<sub>3</sub> in the YRD are strongly recommended to be variable for each season based on various formation mechanisms.
